Award.AbstractNarration:
Contemporary encryption schemes are almost exclusively distribution-agnostic. Their security properties are independent of the statistical characteristics of plaintexts, and the output of these schemes are ciphertexts that are uniformly distributed bit strings, irrespective of use case. While conceptually simple, such encryption schemes fail to meet basic, real-world requirements and have left longstanding functional gaps in key security applications. This project investigates new formalisms and methodologies to guide scientific exploration of such security challenges and yield novel, principled solutions backed by experimental validation and robust, practical design.

The project develops a new framework, called Distribution-Sensitive Cryptography (DSC), for cryptographic tool design that will connect and improve upon several existing primitives and produce entirely new ones. DSC can be applied to create new solutions to security challenges for which good approaches have historically been elusive, including brute-force attacks against password-based encryption, censorship of encrypted protocols, and securing human-generated authentication secrets. The investigators are actively engaged with industry partners, to glean real-world requirements and to transition the new tools into practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to develop novel forms of cryptography under the banner of a concept we call Distribution-Sensitive Cryptography (DSC). The general idea is to improve traditional cryptographic tools such as encryption by studying the messages to which they are applied, developing statistical models for such messages, and leveraging the resulting models to obtain stronger security properties. For example, knowledge of the typical appearance of internet traffic makes it possible to mimic such traffic in formatting private messages, resulting in more effective concealment of these messages---a useful capability for bypassing censorship tools. 

 

Over the course of this project, we performed empirical modeling of a range of real-world applications. We further formulated formal models that reflect these applications’ properties and adversarial environments. We used these foundational results to develop a range of novel and practical security tools and techniques.

 

The intellectual merits of our work are reflected in a range of important outcomes, including novel techniques for robust storage of files, specifically for proving redundant file storage that can resist system degradation and attack; new machine-learning-based password-guessing attacks that surpass the state of the art and can be used by system administrators to identify and harden weak user credentials; techniques to prevent “front-running,” a behavior in trading platforms by which adversaries can gain an unfair advantage over ordinary users; new methods to protect large databases containing biometric data such as fingerprints from compromise; and a cryptographic protocol and accompanying system that enable users to search securely for compromised credentials, such as passwords, in public databases.

 

Our research under this grant has yielded a number of publications in the top conferences in our field, and has had a range of broader impacts. We have educated a wide audience outside of academia about our work through talks, blog posts, press coverage, Reddit participation, and  interaction with industry partners. The work has also created numerous training and educational opportunities for a diverse new generation of undergraduate and graduate students. Through the creation of proofs-of-concept and open-source tools and vigorous interaction with industry partners, our research has additionally benefitted practitioners. Our work has drawn attention to product vulnerabilities and led companies to remediate them, brought to light new techniques that have guided industry system development, and produced state-of-the-art tools adopted by practitioners in deployed systems.
